translated: Sutra of the Wise and Foolish, Scroll 30
Translated by the Yao Qin Dynasty monk Zhu Fonian from Liangzhou
Chapter on Brahmins, Part 2
If one is harmed, just keep the precepts, maintain proper conduct, and control oneself,
This is called a brahmin.

If someone is harmed, do not harbor evil thoughts or have an angry mind. Keep the precepts, be learned, and subdue the mind consciousness. The body is upright like a shadow, and the mind is level and sincere.
Therefore it is said, If one is harmed, just keep the precepts, maintain proper conduct, and control oneself. This is called a brahmin.
Good and evil in the world, long and short, large and small, do not take or give,
This is called a brahmin.

The worldly methods have many kinds. If one wants to observe people's feelings, first collect their words. Speaking good or evil, do not keep it in mind. Do not see long or short, wide or narrow, and also do not see taking or giving. One who fully practices like this is called a brahmin.
Therefore it is said, In the world, good and evil, long and short, large and small, without taking or giving, this is called a brahman.
The body is the basis of practice, speech and mind are without offense, able to accomplish the three realms,
this is called a brahman.
The body does not kill, the mouth does not speak ill, the mind is not jealous, in the world of the five cauldrons, those who can practice these three are called brahmanas.
Therefore it is said, The body is the basis of practice, speech and mind are without offense, able to accomplish the three realms, this is called a brahman.
Coming does not bring joy, going also does not bring sorrow, in the midst of the crowd or away from the crowd,
this is called a brahman.

That practitioner of cultivation holds the mind firmly, unmoved by slander or praise. Seeing those who come, he does not use joy. If he sees those who leave, he also does not use sorrow. Whether in the great assembly or away from the assembly, the mind is always equal, without high or low.
Therefore it is said, Not rejoicing when coming, not grieving when going, being neither attached to nor detached from the world - this is called a brahmin.
Not rejoicing when coming, not grieving when going, being free from sorrow and pure -
this is called a brahmin.
If one sees those who are loved or disliked, one should not give rise to joy.
Why is this so?
Fearing that the mind will become attached and give rise to causes and conditions.
If one sees those who are leaving, one should think to oneself:
I have not offended against anyone, internally and externally pure, with a tranquil mind that does not arise - this is also called a brahmin.

Therefore it is said, Not rejoicing when coming, not grieving when going, being free from sorrow and pure - this is called a brahmin.ğŸ”½Having severed affection and love, leaving the household life without desires, with love and existence already extinguished -ğŸ”½this is called a brahmin.
Having severed affection and love, leaving the household life without desires, with love and existence already extinguished -
this is called a brahmin.

Just as a practitioner cultivates the path, permanently cutting off affection and love, leaving home without desire, wandering freely without obstruction, exhausting all attachment to existence, and being able to fulfill this is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, Cutting off affection and love, leaving home without desire, with attachment to existence already exhausted, this is called a brahman.
Adapting to them, there are none of them, each and every one is non-existent, abandoning craving and desire,
this is called a brahman.

What is called them refers to the external six sense bases, what is called none of them refers to the internal six sense bases. The practitioner holds the intention to contemplate the internal and external sense faculties, all of which are empty and still, abandoning craving and desire, not giving rise to the six sense faculties. One who is able to fulfill this foundation of various practices is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, Adapting to them, there are none of them, each and every one is non-existent, abandoning craving and desire, this is called a brahman.
Adapting to them, there are none of them, each and every one is empty, not tainted by the three realms,
This is called a true brahman.

The practitioner who understands that both internal and external are free from afflictions, and is not attached to the desire realm, form realm, or formless realm, and is able to fully possess such practices, is called a true brahman.
Therefore it is said, When there is no attachment to either, and both are empty, not tainted by the three realms, this is called a true brahman.
Abandoning family affairs, pulling out desires, being free from greed and content,
this is called a true brahman.

People who leave home should not associate with worldly people. Even if they leave home and do not practice the Dharma, violate precepts, are not diligent, or have little learning, they should not sit, stand, or associate with them. They should not think about future gains. One who is able to possess such qualities is called a true brahman.
Therefore it is said, Abandoning family affairs, pulling out desires, being free from greed and content, this is called a true brahman.
Now, knowing this, exhausting the end of suffering, without further desires,
This is called a brahmin.
In the seen Dharma, one is able to discern the subtle and have no evil, knowing that suffering is the root of all illnesses. One who can cut this off is in accord with the subtle.

In the seen Dharma, one does not engage with desires, and anger and delusion are completely exhausted without remainder, free from all bonds and attachments. One who is able to possess this is therefore called a brahmin.
Therefore it is said, Now, knowing this, exhausting the end of suffering, without further desires, this is called a brahmin.
Regarding sin and merit, the two practices are permanently removed, without worry and defilement,
This is called a brahmin.
Even if there is merit, worldly contaminated wholesome roots and virtues attain a human body, but still one is not liberated from birth, old age, sickness, and death.

Moreover, one who commits offenses creates the three roots of evil and goes through birth and death. Offenses and blessings, both are not to be greedily pursued. Completely eliminating both practices, one is free from defilements. One who can practice like this is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, Regarding offenses and blessings, completely eliminating both practices, free from worries and defilements, this is called a brahman.
Regarding offenses and blessings, completely eliminating both practices, unstained by the three realms,
this is called a brahman.

Regarding blessings and offenses, free from desire and attachment, the bliss of meditation in the intermediate state and the bliss of formless meditation, the practitioner completely abandons them, unstained and unattached. Not attached to the three realms - the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm - one who understands this completeness is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, Regarding offenses and blessings, completely eliminating both practices, unstained by the three realms, this is called a brahman.
Just like a flower petal, with a needle piercing a mustard seed,
Not being tainted by desire, that is called a true brahman.

Just as the petals of a lotus are unstained by dust or water, so too is the practitioner who has abandoned desire and is no longer attached to form, sound, smell, taste, touch, or dharmas. It is like trying to pierce a blue bean or a mustard seed with a needle, which is difficult to accomplish.
The practitioner who is free from sexual desire, in brief, is not tainted by evil.
Therefore it is said, Just as the petals of many flowers are unstained by dust or water, not being tainted by desire, that is called a true brahman.
The mind is joyful and free from defilements, like the full moon, slander and criticism are already eliminated,
that is called a true brahman.
Just as the full moon is pure and spotless, free from the five obscurations, surrounded by the stars, emitting great light that illuminates everywhere,

That bhiká¹£u, a practitioner of pure conduct, forever removes the five hindrances and is without the five bonds, his mind attains liberation and the various factors of the path of awakening, he is surrounded by various samÄdhis, he is the sole honored one within them without any faults, he abandons the world's eight dharmas and slander and praise are already removed, one who is able to practice this is therefore called a brÄhmaá¹‡a.
Therefore it is said, the mind is joyful and without defilements, like the full moon, slander and criticism are already removed, this is called a brÄhmaá¹‡a.
Like the clear moon, suspended in the sky, not tainted by desires,
this is called a brÄhmaá¹‡a.

Like the autumn moon is not obscured by the five things, pure and without flaws, emitting great radiance illuminating everywhere, the practicing bhiká¹£u is also like this, not obscured by the five bonds of lust, anger, and delusion, one who is able to practice this is therefore called a brÄhmaá¹‡a.
Therefore it is said, like the clear moon, suspended in the sky, not tainted by desires, this is called a brÄhmaá¹‡a.
Avoiding disputes and not disputing, not being angered by offenses, and treating evil with kindness,
This is called a brahman.
The person who enters concentration does not engage in disputes. With a single mind in meditation, they await joy and comfort, and self-control with the five factors complete is called concentration.
Even if there is evil intent coming towards them, they always treat it with kindness.
Therefore it is said, Avoiding disputes and not disputing, not being angered by offenses, and treating evil with kindness, this is called a brahman.
Understanding subtle wisdom, discerning the path and what is not the path, embodying the supreme meaning,
This is called a brahman.

When people hear of the calculation and measurement of myriad things, the discernment of meanings, the clear understanding of each, the discernment of the path to be taken, knowing what to approach and what to abandon, embodying the supreme meaning,
The so-called supreme meaning is the extinction of nirvana. One who is able to fully possess this Dharma is therefore called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, Understanding subtle wisdom, discerning the path and what is not the path, embodying the supreme meaning, is called a brahman.
Those who, among humans, beg for their own livelihood, without self, without attachment,
Not losing the practice of purity, speaking of wisdom without limit, are called brahmans.

There may be a noble son from a high-ranking family who leaves home to study the path among the four castes, abandoning the mind of arrogance, going from high to low without attachment to glory and hope, wandering and coming and going everywhere.

Engaging in the Buddha's work, respectfully serving the Three Jewels, if obtaining clothing, food, bedding, and medicine for illness, then making prayers of blessing so that the donors receive blessings for generations to come, or using spiritual powers to soar in the sky performing the eighteen transformations, the donors who see this are all delighted, then following to receive the Dharma all attain enlightenment. One who is able to fully practice this is called a brahman.

Therefore it is said, Those who, while in the human realm, beg for their own livelihood, without self, without attachment, not losing the practice of purity, speaking of wisdom without limit, are called Brahmins.
If one can abandon desire, leave home, give up affection, and cut off the defilements of desire,
they are called Brahmins.

If practitioners can completely cut off desire, approach the path, and not give up affection, there may be Brahmins who have not yet reached the ultimate, whose desires are not yet cut off, and who are attached to the five pleasures. Although they are called Brahmins, they are not free from desire.
Those who are learning can permanently extinguish the defilements of desire and not cultivate affection. Those who can fully practice this are called Brahmins.
Therefore it is said, If one can abandon desire, leave home, give up affection, and cut off the defilements of desire, they are called Brahmins.
Having compassion for people, not causing them to be frightened, not harming those who are beneficial,
they are called Brahmins.

The essence of various practices is based on the four immeasurable minds. One should always be compassionate and protect sentient beings. Seeing those who are fearful and sorrowful, one should go and console them, causing them to dwell in peace forever. Not harming others and making offerings, one who can practice this is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, Compassionate towards others, causing them not to be frightened, not harming and benefiting, this is called a brahman.
Avoiding resentment without resentment, without any harm, removing its crookedness,

Therefore it is called a brahman.ğŸ”½The way people hold their intentions and conduct is not the same. With an impartial mind, if one sees an enemy, they are viewed like a newborn baby. Compassionate mind is universally equal, without distinction.

Just like the mind of patience, equal like the earth, like a scale, crawling insects, wriggling creatures, and all breathing beings, viewed like one's own body, thought of like a father, thought of like a mother, thought of like a child, thought of like one's own body, without any difference.
One who is able to practice these various things is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, Avoiding resentment without resentment, without harm or injury, removing wrong views, is called a brahman.
In the future, in the past, and in the present, there is nothing, and nothing to grasp or abandon,
This is called a brahman.

Just as a person in the future does not commit various evil deeds, has not committed, and will not commit, in the past he has not committed various evil deeds, has not committed, and will not commit, in the present he does not commit, and in the middle he does not commit various evil deeds or not commit various evil deeds, has not committed, and will not commit.
One who is able to abandon these various evil deeds is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, In the future, in the past, and in the present, there is nothing, and nothing to grasp or abandon, this is called a brahman.
Removing lust, anger, delusion, arrogance, and all evil, like a needle piercing a mustard seed,
This is called a true Brahmin.

Just as a practitioner who wishes to defile the mind cannot reach the path of emptiness and tranquility, and cannot remove arrogance and other unwholesome states, and can only gradually advance to the realm of nirvana, just as a needle cannot penetrate a mustard seed.
The mind is also like this. It is not bound by lust, anger, and delusion. One who possesses this practice is called a true Brahmin.
Therefore it is said, Removing lust, anger, and delusion, arrogance and all evils, like a needle penetrating a mustard seed, is called a true Brahmin.
A city is fortified by moats, and those who come and go suffer from it.
If one wishes to cross to the other shore, but is unwilling to accept the words of others,
Only being able to extinguish and not arise, this is called a true Brahmin.

The cycle of birth and death is long and enduring, and the suffering experienced is countless. Only those who practice meditation can transcend the difficulties of this cycle of birth and death, remove wrong and doubtful thoughts, and have no more hesitation. Abandoning the bonds of afflictions, they accept the bonds of purity.
One who possesses this is called a brahman.

Therefore it is said, The city is made strong by moats, those who come and go suffer from this, wishing to cross to the other shore, unwilling to accept the words of others, only able to extinguish and not arise, this is called a brahman.
People who can cut off craving in this world and the next, with craving already exhausted,
are called brahmans.

As long as the roots of craving are not exhausted, one does not reach the Way. Only after the roots of craving are exhausted can one practice the Way. Those who seek the Way but do not cut off the bonds of the three realms do not reach the Way. Only after being able to cut off the roots of craving can one reach the Way. One who is able to possess this is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, People who can cut off craving in this world and the next, with craving already exhausted, are called brahmans.
People who have no hopes in this world and the next, because of having no hopes,
are called brahmans.

What is meant by hope? All the myriad things in the world are what people hope for, but because of this hope, they have not yet been cut off. Even now, while the present body is alive and exists in the world, even if in the next life one takes its end, when the body dies and the spirit departs, there is no more hope.
Those who are able to be endowed with such merit are called Brahmins.
Therefore it is said, A person without hope, in this world and the next, by being without hope, is called a Brahmin.
Not knowing oneself, the devas and Gandharvas, knowing immeasurable observation,
are called Brahmins.
When the Buddha TathÄgata was sitting in meditation, the devas and worldly people did not know where the Buddha was.
There was a bhiká¹£u named Taqiecha who went to where the World-Honored One was and then praised the TathÄgata with this verse:
I take refuge in the Honored One among humans, I take refuge in the Supreme One among humans,
I do not know what kind of meditation the World-Honored One relies on now.
I only wish that the Heavenly Among the Heavens will expound its teaching and meaning.
The TathÄgata said by himself:

Among the practices of purity, there is no one who surpasses me. The reason I know this is so is that meditation, liberation, right concentration, and samÄdhi are still the common dharmas of the world. The devas, nÄgas, and spirits cannot know where I am, let alone the wondrous gate of the many knowledges of the Buddha's activities that I will practice.
Can the devas, nÄgas, ghosts, and spirits know where I am?
Therefore it is said, Not knowing by oneself, the devas and gandharvas know the immeasurable contemplation. This is called a brÄhmaá¹‡a.
Knowing one's past lives, seeing the paths of devas and humans, knowing the source of suffering in birth,
The mind of wisdom is eternally tranquil.

One can know the affairs of hell and heaven in countless past lives, but others cannot. Only the Buddha, the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, can observe the trichiliocosm like observing a pearl in the palm, knowing the source of suffering in birth and thoroughly understanding its basis. With swift wisdom, one quickly attains the path of arhatship, and whatever one thinks of is unobstructed.
Therefore it is said, Knowing one's past lives, seeing the paths of gods and humans, knowing the source of suffering in birth, the enlightened mind is eternally tranquil.
Knowing one's own mind is liberated, liberated from desires and unattached,
Accomplishing the three insights, this is called a brahman.
Like a practitioner who knows what the mind thinks, knowing clearly those who are liberated and those who are not, and forever attaining liberation from all conceptualized practices.
The so-called three insights are knowing one's past lives, having the heavenly eye, and ending outflows. One who fully practices like this is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, Knowing one's own mind is liberated, free from desires and attachments, and accomplishing the three insights, this is called a brahmin.
Recognizing one's past lives, knowing the causes and conditions of sentient beings,
The TathÄgata, the Buddha, is unattached, this is called a brahmin.

At that time, the TathÄgata knew countless matters, observing the natures and practices of sentient beings, each and every one clear. He fully understood those who were born and those who died, just as when rain from the heavens universally moistens the world. At that time, the World-Honored One observed the various kinds of birth and death in the same way, with none of those born or dying not being observed and cultivated.
At that time, the World-Honored One was alone with ÅšÄriputra in a quiet room, enjoying each other's company.
At that time, there was someone who had already taken their last breath and passed away, dwelling in the intermediate state between lives, their spirit not changing.
The Buddha said to ÅšÄriputra:
You should now observe this consciousness-spirit in the intermediate state between lives. From where did it come?
If it moves again, where will it go?
At that time, ÅšÄriputra immediately entered the four dhyÄna concentrations and contemplated from where this person's spirit had come.
If it were to move and change, where would it go?
At that time, ÅšÄriputra did not know from where this person had come.
Where would it go?
At that time, the World-Honored One told ÅšÄriputra:
What you see now does not reach the realm of the buddhas. The countless worlds from where this spirit came are not something that your spiritual powers can see.
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:
You should observe again where this spirit will be reborn.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra again entered samÄdhi, but did not know where the spirit had gone. ÅšÄriputra then arose from samÄdhi and addressed the Buddha, saying:
Today, I entered concentration and observed the world everywhere, but did not know where the spirit had gone.
The Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:
This spirit will today pass over another one billion worlds and will be reborn in such-and-such a family with such-and-such a surname and such-and-such a name.
What the TathÄgata sees is not something that Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas can know. Only the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, attains this knowledge of past lives.
Therefore it is said, Knowing one's own past lives and the causes and conditions of sentient beings, the TathÄgata, the Buddha, is unattached. This is called a brÄhmaá¹‡a.
Completely severing all bonds, yet not having any vexation,
The TathÄgata, the Buddha, is unattached. This is called a brÄhmaá¹‡a.

All sentient beings who sever all bonds and afflictions, although arhats and pratyekabuddhas sever the bonds and afflictions, they still have similar bonds remaining. The World-Honored Buddhas have no similarity. Therefore the TathÄgata, the Buddha, is unattached.
Therefore it is said:
Completely severing all bonds,
Yet not having any vexation,
The TathÄgata, the Buddha, is unattached.
This is called a brÄhmaá¹‡a.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The sage is the foremost among dragons, the great sage is the most honored,
Bathed by countless Buddhas, this is called a brahman.
As for the so-called sages, they attain the five supernatural powers, are the most honored among the masses, and have nothing above them. Internally and externally clear, without many flaws.
Sages are also called elephants, nurturing the body to be the largest among animals, with a firm intention that can repel many enemies.
Bathed by countless [Buddhas], as for the so-called bathing, it is the eight liberations and the right bathing pool, removing all dust and impurities without any afflictions.
When the TathÄgata extends his hand, where the hand reaches dust and impurities do not stick, and evil people who observe cannot take advantage.
Therefore it is said, the sage is the foremost among dragons, the great sage is the most honored, bathed by countless Buddhas, this is called a brahman.
Having exhausted all that exists, crossing the stream without outflows, from here crossing to the other shore,
This is called a brahman.
The practitioner completely transcends all dharmas, and clearly and distinctly understands that all that exists in the world is non-existent.
What is called flowing has four names:
First, the flow of desire, second, the flow of existence, third, the flow of ignorance, and fourth, the flow of views.
One who crosses these four flows will then attain the practice of no outflows.

Arhats and pratyekabuddhas still contemplate the acceptance of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, heat, and peak dharmas. Although they can contemplate contaminated worldly dharmas, the mind is still bound. Sometimes, they first think of contaminated dharmas and then think of the uncontaminated. Therefore, the deeply hidden treasury of the TathÄgata has a great deficiency.

The TathÄgata, the Great Sage, focuses his mind on meditation, from existence to non-existence. In observing the dharmas of no-outflows, he has never been lacking. He attains all the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, firmly remembers and does not forget. The ten powers, the four forms of fearlessness, great kindness, great compassion, the three unobstructed paths, and the practices of the supernormal powers - these are called the dharmas cultivated by the TathÄgata, not the dharmas cultivated by arhats and pratyekabuddhas.
Therefore it is said, Destroying all that exists, crossing the stream of no-outflows, going beyond this shore - this is called a brahmin.
Without meditation, without speaking, also not thinking of evil, meditation and wisdom are pure,
this is called a brahmin.
The practitioner does not think of evil meditation. When entering meditation, one has no words or speech, always thinking of good dharmas.

If one sees scolding, one just guards the Dharma. If one attains the meditation of flavor correspondence and the intermediate meditation, one holds the intention and guards it without disturbance. One who is able to fully possess this practice is called a brahmin.
Therefore it is said, Without meditation and without speaking, not thinking of evil, meditation and wisdom are pure, this is called a brahmin.
The monk's charnel ground robe, contemplating desire as false,
Sitting under a tree in an empty and quiet place, this is called a brahmin.
There are four kinds of charnel ground robes:

First, those who leave home and go forth to study wear robes given by their families; second, robes given by donors are received and guarded; third, a hundred patches are made from various discarded remnants; fourth, the charnel ground robe is defiled and impure.

When the TathÄgata first studied and left home to wear the robe given by his family, he contemplated desire as false, abandoned sixty thousand wives, renounced the status of a wheel-turning king, left home to study the path, sat under a tree, subdued MÄra, and defeated eighteen koá¹­is of his followers.
Because he is able to possess these many virtues, he is called a brahmin.
Therefore it is said, The monk's charnel ground robe, contemplating desire as false, sitting under a tree in an empty and quiet place, this is called a brahmin.
People have no recognition, no speech, no expression, and their bodies are cold without warmth,
This is called a brahman.

When the TathÄgata appears in the world, there is nothing he does not know and nothing he does not encompass. As for having no speech or expression, he forever eliminates doubts and does not harbor hesitation. The bonds and afflictions of all afflictions are completely extinguished without remainder, and he attains the cessation of the sweet dew. Because he is able to possess these various practices, he is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, people have no recognition, no speech, no expression, and their bodies are cold without warmth, this is called a brahman.
Abandoning the home life, without the fears of a household, attaining the cessation of the sweet dew,
This is called a brahman.

The reason for living in a household is to provide comfort for the people and enable them to live their lives. The body is the house of various bonds, and therefore the sages teach people to leave their homes and dwell in seclusion, seeking the cessation of the sweet dew. Because they are able to possess these various virtues, they are called brahmans.
Therefore it is said, Abandoning the household life, without the fears of a household, attaining the deathless cessation, this is called a brahmin.
Cutting off worldly affairs, with no harsh words, the eightfold path is true,
This is called a brahmin.

The World-Honored One's light and appearance were radiant. He first turned the Dharma wheel, and 80,000 devas, two kings' people, seven brahmins, King BimbisÄra of Magadha and 12,000 people, in the Stone Room in the realm of Magadha, Åšakra DevÄnÄm Indra and 12,000 devas, in the country of KuÅ›inagara, he finally liberated Subhadra.

After the Buddha's parinirvÄá¹‡a, there will be an arhat who appears in the world, named UpÄli. In the meantime, he will liberate countless beings and expound the unobstructed Dharma of the eightfold path.
Therefore it is said, Cutting off worldly affairs, with no harsh words, the eightfold path is true, this is called a brahmin.
Traveling far alone, hidden and formless, difficult to subdue but able to subdue,
This is called a brahman.

Like a practitioner who gives rise to boundless thoughts and scatters limitless thoughts, the physical body is here while the mind is on the other side of the ocean. It is very difficult to observe and know the form and appearance of the mind.
The mind and thoughts race and in the time it takes to snap one's fingers, they pass through countless millions of rivers, mountains, and oceans. Therefore, it is said to travel far alone.
There is also a question: The mind has the ten great mental factors, with the mind being the eleventh. Why is it said to travel far alone?
The answer is:

The mind always follows conditions and acts according to what is present. When the mind is on form and sound, there is no smell, taste, or tactile objects;ğŸ”½When the mind is on smell, there is no form, taste, or tactile objects;ğŸ”½When the mind is on taste, there is no form, smell, or tactile objects;
When the mind is on tactile objects, there is no form, sound, smell, or taste;
The mind is in the Dharma, with five unsurpassed things.
When the mind is in form, it is the basis of the Dharma, just as when a king goes out, his retinue and attendants are all complete, but he is called the king.

This is also like this. The mind creates causes and conditions, and the ten dharmas are all present, but it does not receive the name. It is also like a flying bird flying in the sky, relying on its six feathers, but it is only called a bird.

This is also like this. The mind has no form and no nest, and it is not seen by the flesh eyes of worldly people. It relies on the five aggregates. When the aggregates disperse, it is separated and does not have a physical substance. The mind is difficult to transform, just like wood drilling steel.

Therefore, the sages left teachings for later generations. Those who want to subdue the mind should use a hundred medicines in the morning, a hundred medicines at noon, and a hundred medicines in the evening. Emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness, tranquility, contemplation, and cessation are used to treat mental illnesses and make them cured. One who can do this is called a brahman.
Therefore it is said, Far gone, wandering alone, hidden without form, difficult to subdue, able to subdue, this is called a brahman.
Formless and invisible, this is also invisible.
One who understands this phrase, mindfulness then has a basis.
Aware and knowing the exhaustion of afflictions, this is the world's foremost brahman.
What is meant by formless and invisible?
It refers to the mind.

The mind gives rise to troubles and brings about misfortune for the body, just like an elephant or horse that is unruly and untamed. A person with eyes would use whips and sticks to make it know pain, and only then can it be disciplined and gentle.
The human mind causes trouble and leads one to hell, hungry ghosts, and animals. Although one may become a human, one will be born in a lowly and ugly form, and be envied by others.
Therefore it is said, Formless and invisible, this is also invisible.
One who understands this phrase, who is mindful and has a basis, who realizes the exhaustion of afflictions, is the foremost brahmin in the world.

The reason why the World-Honored Buddhas appear in the world is precisely to subdue this evil and wicked mind. The World-Honored Buddhas have compassion for all, their vast compassion covers everywhere, and although they dwell in the world, they are unstained and unattached.
Cutting off the river of birth and death, able to endure and transcend, self-awakened and escaping the moat,
This is called a brahmin.
Like the practitioner who is bound by the five desires, wandering in the river of birth and death, he must rely on the great sage's guidance and authority to reach the other shore from this shore.
